questions.question: A case of death of a married female within 3 years of marriage was reported. Inquest is done by?
questions.explanation: is mandatory in specific cases, including the death of a married woman within 7 years of marriage under suspicious circumstances. Since the case involves the death of a married female within 3 years of marriage, it falls under the purview of a Magistrate Inquest, ensuring a thorough investigation into any possible foul play (such as dowry death or homicide). In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest. 1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS) Most common type of inquest in India. Conducted by a police officer , generally not below the rank of Head Constable . 2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS) Conducted by an Executive Magistrate , or Judicial Magistrate . It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including: Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody or any custody authorized by the court Deaths due to police firing Deaths in jail Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if, Commits suicide In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf There is any doubt regarding the cause of death Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate. The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death. Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests: Feature Police Inquest Magistrate Inquest Conducted by Police officer Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate) Involvement of witnesses Requires signatures of panchas Does not require witness signatures Witness statements Admissible in court Not admissible in court Can order arrest No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses Can issue arrest warrants Exhumation Cannot order exhumation Can order exhumation of a body Autopsy orders Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately Orders autopsy only when necessary Forensic analysis Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera Can order chemical analysis Judicial (Option A): While a Judicial Magistrate can conduct an inquest, the term "Judicial" alone is too broad and not specific to the context of this question. questions.question: Which of the following does not constitute grievous hurt under Section 320 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 7 days hospital admission Explanation BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous: Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury). (Option A ruled out) Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear. (Option C ruled out) Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint. Permanent disfiguration of head or face. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth. (Option B ruled out) Any hurt which endangers life , or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 20 days , in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, page 296 https://www.mha.gov.in/sites/default/files/250883_english_01042024.pdf https://bprd.nic.in/uploads/pdf/COMPARISON%20SUMMARY%20BNS%20to%20IPC%20.pdf
